title-group.article-title: Equal modal damping design for a family of resonant vibration control formats

abstract.p: The principle of equal modal damping is used to give a unified presentation and calibration of resonant control of structures for different control formats, based on velocity, acceleration–position or position feedback. When introducing a resonant controller the original resonant mode splits into two, and if these are required to have the same modal damping ratio, the characteristic equation conforms to a two-parameter format. By selecting a suitable relative separation of the modal frequencies, the design problem defines a one-parameter family – determined, for example, in terms of the resulting modal damping ratio. While velocity feedback, and the associated acceleration–position formats, lead to near-equal resonant peak heights of the velocity in a frequency response diagram, position feedback leads to balanced acceleration peaks. It is demonstrated, how a simple additional time derivative term in the control coupling can change these properties into balanced position and velocity peaks, respectively. In particular this gives an improved control format based on measurement of structural displacement or deformation. In all cases the optimal calibration in terms of a root locus identification leads to a simple explicit pair of design formulae for controller frequency and damping ratio based on a simple two -degrees-of-freedom system. Unconditional stability is demonstrated for a general multi-degrees-of-freedom system with multiple controllers for the velocity and acceleration-velocity formats, while the position and extended position feedback format give a simple stability condition in terms of the gain factors and the structure flexibility matrix. The paper concludes with a simple design procedure based on the desired effective damping of a flexible structure with equal modal control in any of the discussed resonant formats.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Classic collocated control is basically equivalent to local pure viscous damping, implemented by direct velocity feedback in Balas (1979), or by integral force feedback in Preumont (2002) and Preumont et al. (2008). These basic methods are typically very effective, stable and robust, but are not targeted directly at one or several specific modes of a flexible structure. For damping of particular vibration modes it is common to apply either Independent Modal Space Control (Meirovitch, 1990) where an LQ (linear–quadratic) format is designed for the target modes, or simple collocated feedback control through a resonant second-order filter. The present paper is devoted to a general format for resonant control, based on one or more collocated sensor–actuator pairs.

The classic resonant control formats are the positive position feedback and the acceleration feedback, see Preumont (2002). In the positive position feedback the position, strain or extension at the sensor–actuator location is measured and passed through a resonant second-order filter. A stability condition is derived in Fanson and Caughey (1990), stating that the negative stiffness imposed by the control must not make the effective stiffness matrix singular. The efficiency of resonant control requires that the filter frequency is not too far removed from the frequency of the target mode of the structure, and that the bandwidth of the filter is appropriately balanced to give the desired dissipation. In Fanson and Caughey (1990) the frequency ratio is 2 and filter damping is 20% of critical.

In acceleration feedback the acceleration is measured and passed through a resonant filter. As demonstrated by Sim and Lee (1993) this procedure is unconditionally stable. Under special feedback conditions stability can also be demonstrated by identifying an analogy with a passive, and thereby inherently stable, mechanical vibration absorber, where the absorber mass is connected to the structure through a spring and dashpot placed in series, see Snowdon (1959). A tuning procedure for acceleration feedback is presented by Goh and Yan (1996), where the choice of unit frequency ratio and critical filter damping leads to design at the cross-over point in the root locus diagram. The performance of the acceleration feedback procedure has been illustrated in de Noyer and Hanagud (1998), while the application for active vibration isolation is considered in Kim et al. (2008).

Alternative resonant control concepts can be formulated in terms of so-called virtual vibration absorbers, where equivalent mechanical systems are obtained by combining mass, spring and dash-pot elements in a suitable network. As demonstrated by Juang and Phan (1992) the classic tuned mass damper is equivalent to a modified version of acceleration feedback. Initial design and experimental verification of this equivalent model have been presented in Lee-Glauser et al. (1995), whereas explicit calibration formulae, taking into account the influence of higher vibration modes, are given in Krenk and Høgsberg (2009). More elaborate and advanced virtual vibration absorber concepts have recently been introduced in Wu (2002) and Wu and Shao (2007).

To a large extent both the development and the applications of resonant control strategies have been driven by the piezoelectric sensor–actuator community, see the review by Moheimani (2003). The equivalence between a resonant shunted piezoelectric transducer and the mechanical tuned mass damper was described by Hagood and von Flotow (1991). They also considered an RL (resistance–inductance) electrical circuit that is commonly applied for passive resonant damping of flexible structures, see Pota et al. (2002), Tjahyadi et al. (2006) and Preumont et al. (2008). The components of the resonant circuit can either be placed in series or in parallel, where the parallel version is most widely used. In Kim et al. (2011a) the passive parallel RL network is calibrated based on the frequency response procedure by Den Hartog (1956), whereby the dynamic amplification at two fixed points are equal. As demonstrated in Krenk (2005) this corresponds to equal damping in the two corresponding modes. A related approach was proposed in Hagood and von Flotow (1991), where the maximum dynamic amplification is minimized. Hereby, the frequency tuning becomes slightly different and the equal modal damping property is lost. A review of calibration procedures for RL-circuits is given in Caruso (2001). Piezoelectric elements are generally suitable for measuring and imposing strain, corresponding to active control by position feedback. A consistent stability analysis and a numerical design strategy for the positive position feedback is given in Moheimani et al. (2006), and recent applications of the positive position feedback are reported in Mahmood and Moheimani (2009) and Ahmed and Pota (2011). Acceleration feedback control has two basic advantages over positive position feedback: No static feed-through and unconditional stability. The direct output of a piezoelectric transducer represents strain and it may therefore be advantageous to place the double derivative for acceleration feedback in the controller equation (Kim et al., 2011b) introducing the so-called negative position feedback. This type of control is equivalent to acceleration feedback (Sim and Lee, 1993) but implies a double differentiation that may amplify high-frequency noise. An alternative implementation of resonant acceleration feedback appears as electromagnetic shunt damping where an electromagnet is coupled to a circuit in which the resonant property is generated via an external capacitance C, supplemented by additional resistance and inductance. The concept was originally proposed by Behrens et al. (2005) and developed in Inoue et al. (2008) and Cheng and Oh (2009), while a nonresonant calibration was used by Niu et al. (2009).

Higher order versions of both positive position and acceleration feedback have been proposed by Mahmoodi and Ahmadian (2009, 2010), where the classic resonant filter equations are supplemented by a first-order filter with the objective to enhance the resulting damping of the control system. The augmentation of the system increases the order of the characteristic polynomial, making the derivation of explicit analytical design expressions difficult. Thus, in these cases the design is based on a numerical optimization procedure implying a minimization of a suitable quadratic cost function.

The present paper introduces a simple general design procedure for resonant controllers in any of the previously discussed formats. When a controller is introduced to act in resonance with a selected mode, this mode splits into two modes with closely spaced frequencies. By tuning the resonant controller frequency. these closely spaced modes can be given equal damping ratio. For increasing damping ratio of the resonant controller the modal damping of the two coupled modes increases, while the two frequencies approach each other. The optimal controller damping ratio constitutes a compromise between introducing sufficient modal damping and avoiding additive response in the two split modes. The optimal design parameters can be expressed in simple analytic form using only the complex root locus diagram for an equivalent two-degrees-of-freedom system as illustrated in the next section. The following sections deal with each of the particular resonant formats in turn.

sec.title: 2. Basic equations
sec.p:
The principle and the notation are illustrated in Figure 1 showing a beam and a local sensor with frequency characteristic G(ω) and a collocated actuator with frequency characteristic F(ω). In the following different forms of the functions G(ω) and F(ω) will be discussed, representing different forms of implementing resonant control, e.g. acceleration–position or position–position control. The basic properties of the structure used in the calibration procedure are identified via an equivalent model equation (1)mrx··+crx·+krx=fc+f with mass mr, viscous damping parameter cr and equivalent spring stiffness kr. The representative displacement is x(t) and the load consists of an external load component f(t) and the controller force fc(t). It is convenient to make use of the normalized equation of motion (2)x··+2ζrωrx·+ωr2x=ωr2fc+fkr in terms of the natural frequency ωr = (kr/mr)1/2 and the damping ratio ζr=1/2cr/(mrkr)1/2. For flexible structures the model parameters are expressed in terms of modal properties and x is the displacement associated with the resonant mode as discussed in detail later. The resonant controller is described by the second-order equation (3)ξ··+2ζcωcξ·+ωc2ξ=ωr2g with natural controller frequency ωc and equivalent controller damping ratio ζc. The controller equation is normalized such that the control variable ξ(t) has the same dimension as the sensor signal g(t). Figure 1.
Flexible structure with collocated resonant vibration control.

The control force fc and the response output g are linear frequency-dependent functions of the control variable ξ and the structural displacement x, respectively (4)fc/kr=F(ω)ξ g=G(ω)x The idea of resonant control is the use of a controller frequency close to the natural system frequency to be controlled, ωc ≃ ωr. Thus, for excitation at a frequency ω around the resonance frequency the first and last term on the left-hand side of the structural equation (2) and the controller equation (3) will cancel approximately. The response will then be governed by the middle term, representing the damping via the coefficients ζr and ζc. Substitution of the frequency representation (4) of the coupling terms leads to the approximate response at resonance (5)x≈1/2iζeqfkr where the equivalent damping ratio is (6)ζeq≈ζr+F(ωr)G(ωr)4ζc This relation illustrates the basic requirement that the product F(ω)G(ω) should have a dominating positive real part around the resonance frequency, and that the controller damping parameter ζc must be ‘small’ for the device to be effective around resonance.

There are several simple formats in which the product F(ω)G(ω) is real and positive, e.g. position feedback. This reduces the frequency functions F and G to constants with the same sign. Velocity feedback on both x and ξ would introduce the imaginary unit i in both F(ω) and G(ω) and one of the coupling terms would therefore need a minus. This format is easily transformed into an alternative format, in which one of the coupling terms is an acceleration, while the other is a direct ‘position’ term. The transformation establishes a direct equivalence as demonstrated below, and the difference between the various formats is therefore mainly a question related to the implementation of the control scheme. The basic resonance properties are identified by a root locus analysis in the following section, while specific implementation formats are treated in Sections 3–6 and demonstrated in relation to a flexible structure in Section 7.

sec.title: 2.1. Root locus analysis
sec.p: It is assumed that the coupling functions F(ω) and G(ω) are polynomials in ω of degree less than or equal to two, corresponding to the original equations being coupled via differential operators of at most second order. In that case the frequency response function of the system will have a denominator in the form of a quartic polynomial. The roots of this characteristic polynomial define several of the basic properties of the combined system response. It was demonstrated in Krenk (2005) that the classic frequency tuning procedure for the tuned mass absorber, traditionally carried out via equal amplification at two particular ‘fix point’ frequencies (Den Hartog, 1956), leads to equal modal damping ratio of the two free vibration modes of the coupled system. Thus, the frequency tuning for this type of resonant damping problem can be turned into a procedure, in which the poles are placed such that equal modal damping is attained.

Let the four roots of the characteristic polynomial be denoted ω1, … , ω4, and assume that there is a parameter combination for which ω1 and ω2 lie in the first quadrant of the complex plane. The corresponding modes will then have equal damping ratio, if ω1 and ω2 lie on the same line containing the origin of the complex plane as illustrated in Figure 2. This implies that they are inverse points in the complex plane with respect to some real-valued frequency ω0, i.e. (7)ω2ω0=ω0ω1* where ω1* denotes the conjugate of ω1. The reciprocal relation between ω/ω0 and ω0/ω suggests the following format of the characteristic equation (8)(ωω0-ω0ω)2-4iλχ(ωω0-ω0ω)-4χ2=0 This equation contains two coefficients, and it turns out to be convenient to express these in terms of the real-valued nondimensional parameters χ and λ as shown. The corresponding polynomial form follows from multiplication with (ω0ω)2 (9)ω4-(2+4χ2)ω02ω2+ω04-4iλχω0ω(ω2-ω02)=0 It is seen that the reference frequency ω0 is defined by the constant term of the normalized characteristic polynomial. The special property of equally damped modes as expressed by the inverse root relation (7) is equivalent to imposing a balance between the cubic and linear terms, whereby they cancel at the frequency ω = ±ω0. Figure 2.
Complex roots ω1, ω2 and ω3, ω4 as inverse points of circle |ω| = ω0.

The root locus diagram of the quartic equation (9) is easily analyzed by reverting to the quadratic format (8). This format permits determination of the expression inside the parenthesis, and ω then follows from solving a quadratic equation, see Krenk (2005) and Krenk and Høgsberg (2009) for details. The results are illustrated in Figure 3. For λ = 0 there is no damping, and the natural frequencies ω1 and ω2 appear as points on the positive real axis. When increasing λ for a fixed value of the parameter χ < 1, the roots move into the complex plane as illustrated in Figure 3(a). It follows from the inverse point property, illustrated in Figure 2, that the two roots ω1 and ω2 have equal argument, corresponding to equal damping of the corresponding free modes. This situation changes at the bifurcation point ωb, which is reached for λ = 1. The roots then branch off along a circle with radius |ω| = ω0 centered at the origin. One branch follows the circle towards the real axis while the other branch reaches a new branch point on the imaginary axis for λ = (χ + χ−1)/2. Figure 3.
Root locus diagram: (a)χ = 0.4, λ = 0, 0.05, 0.10…; (b)χ = 0, 0.05, 0.10, … , λ=2/2.

The parameter values of interest in connection with control and damping of structures correspond to the first part where the roots are inverse points in the circle, i.e. the parameter interval 0 < λ ≤ 1. In this parameter interval the two complex roots have the form (10)ω1,2=|ω1,2|(1-ζ2+iζ) where ζ is the common damping ratio of the two modes. A simple expression for the modal damping ratio ζ in terms of the system parameters λ and χ can be obtained by using the fact that the coefficient of the cubic term in (9) is the sum of the four roots ω1,…, ω4. When using the special properties of the four roots illustrated in Figure 2, the following expression is obtained for the damping ratio (Krenk, 2005) (11)ζ=λχ1/2(|ω1|ω0+ω0|ω1|)≈λχ where the latter approximation is valid for small values of χ, typical of practice.

At first glance it may appear desirable to choose λ = 1 corresponding to the bifurcation point, as this introduces maximum damping in the modes, see Hagood and von Flotow (1991), Goh and Yan (1996), and Caruso (2001). However, the choice of the bifurcation point also implies identical angular frequency of the modes and thereby leads to constructive interference of the two modes. As demonstrated in Krenk (2005), an optimal balance between the obtained damping and a suitable separation of the vibration frequencies leads to the parameter value λ=1/22. The local part of the corresponding root locus diagram is illustrated in Figure 3(b). The two roots ω1 and ω2 move into the complex plane along curves forming an angle of ±45° with the real axis, leading to a modal damping ratio of (12)ζ≈1/22χ In the following, optimal control parameters will be identified by identification of the appropriate coefficients of the characteristic polynomial of the control formats with the coefficients of the normalized quartic equation (9).

sec.title: 3. Velocity feedback control
sec.p: In the case of velocity feedback the normalized structural equation (2) takes the form (13)x··+2ζrωrx·+ωr2x=αωcξ·+ωr2fkr where α is a nondimensional positive gain factor. The corresponding control equation is (14)ξ··+2ζcωcξ·+ωc2ξ=-ωcx· where a minus is introduced according to the discussion in connection with the generic expression (6) for the response at resonance. The factor ωc has been introduced in both feedback terms to give x and ξ the same dimension. The structural response x follows from introducing the frequency representations in (13) and (14), whereby (15)x=(ωc2-ω2+2iζcωcω)ωr2(ωr2-ω2+2iζrωrω)(ωc2-ω2+2iζcωcω)-αωc2ω2fkr The last factor on the right-hand side represents the quasi-static response, and the first factor is therefore the dynamic amplification.

sec.title: 3.1. Parameter calibration
sec.p: The calibration of the control parameters ωc and ζc is based on the denominator of the frequency response function when ignoring the structural damping, i.e. ζr = 0, whereby (16)D1(ω)=ω4-[ωr2+(1+α)ωc2]ω2+ωr2ωc2 -2iζcωcω[ω2-ωr2]. The optimal controller parameters now follow from identification of this quartic polynomial with the generic equal modal damping ratio equation (9).

The controller frequency is found by determining the characteristic reference frequency ω0 in two different ways. First via the ratio of the coefficients to the linear and the cubic term, and then from the constant term, (17)ω02=ωr2 and ω04=ωr2ωc2 Elimination of ω02 between these equations gives the controller frequency as (18)ωc=ωr i.e. the controller frequency is to be taken equal to the resonant frequency of the uncontrolled structure.

The controller damping ratio ζc is found by expressing the generic parameter χ from the coefficient of the quadratic term as well as from the coefficient of the cubic term. Identification of these two coefficients leads to (19)4χ2=α and 4λχω0=2ζcωc When using the optimal frequency separation parameter λ=2/2 and the previously determined values ω0 = ωc = ωr, elimination of the parameter χ between the two equations determines the controller damping ratio as (20)ζc2=1/2α It is important to note that there is a simple relation between the modal damping ratio ζ and the damping ratio ζc of the controller. When eliminating the parameters α and χ between (12), (19) and (20), it follows that (21)ζ≈1/2ζc i.e. the modal damping ratio ζ is approximately equal to half of the controller damping ratio ζc. This is an essential result that permits explicit design of the controller from the desired modal damping ratio.

The reduction of the response obtained by velocity feedback control is illustrated by frequency response graphs for the displacement amplitude from (15) and the corresponding velocity amplitude for the idealized two-degrees-of-freedom system with ζr = 0 in Figure 4. The effect of multiple degrees of freedom and structural damping is discussed in detail later in Section 7, where a simple explicit formula accounting for the effect of structural damping is developed. In addition to the frequency response curves the graphs also indicate by light dashed curves the character and location of the resonant ‘plateau’ generated by the velocity control, when calibrated by the equal modal damping procedure. The velocity control procedure generates a nearly level resonant plateau of the velocity response. The frequency response of the displacement amplitude is essentially an integral of the velocity response curve with respect to the angular frequency ω, and therefore the displacement response curves exhibit a central ‘level’ part described by the dashed curves ∝ (ω0/ω). In the present case the three characteristic frequencies are identical, ω0 = ωc = ωr, and the dashed ‘plateau curves’ pass through the appropriate response magnitude at this frequency as indicated by dots in the figure. The displacement amplification at the characteristic frequency ω0 follows from (15) as xkr/f = 1/ζc. Thus, the dynamic amplification for α = 0.02 is 10, while a four-fold increase of the gain to α = 0.08 reduces the dynamic amplification to 5, i.e. by a factor of two. These simple relations are the basis of the control design procedure developed in Section 7. Figure 4.
Velocity feedback: (a) displacement amplitude and (b) velocity amplitude for α = 0.02, 0.04, 0.08 corresponding to ζc = 0.10, 0.14 and 0.20.

Many design procedures for resonant control use a larger controller damping ratio corresponding to the bifurcation point ωb in the generic root locus plane shown in Figure 3. In the present notation this corresponds to selecting the controller damping ratio as ζc2=α. When using this value the nearly flat plateau of the frequency response curves is replaced by a uni-modal peak with dynamic amplification xf/kr=2/ζc at the angular frequency ω0. This is illustrated in Figure 5, where the response amplitude curves with the present balanced modal damping calibration are shown with a solid line, while the response curves from bifurcation point calibration are shown as dashed lines. It is clearly seen, how the bifurcation point calibration lifts the amplification curves in the resonant interval with a maximum increase of 2 at ω0. Figure 5.
Frequency response amplitude for velocity feedback with ζc2=1/2α (—) and ζc2=α (– – –) for α = 0.02, 0.04 and 0.08.

sec.title: 3.2. Multi-degrees-of-freedom implementation and stability
sec.p: The equations of motion of a multi-degrees-of-freedom system are typically formulated in terms of displacements x. For linear systems the equation of motion is defined in terms of the mass matrix M, the stiffness matrix K and a damping matrix D. The load consists of the external force vector f and a force vector generated by the control signals ξ = [ξ1,…, ξm]. In the present format the m control forces are proportional to the controller signal with gain factors contained in the diagonal matrix β = ⌈β1, … , βm⌋. These forces act on the displacement components of the structure as specified by the n × m connectivity matrix W. The resulting equation for the structure is (22)Mx··+Dx·+Kx=WΩcβξ·+f In this format the control signal is scaled by the diagonal frequency matrix Ωc = ⌈ω1, … , ωm⌋, containing the natural frequencies of the resonant controller equations (23)ξ··+Dcξ·+Ωc2ξ=-ΩcWTx· The controller bandwidth is specified via the diagonal damping matrix Dc = ⌈2ζ1ω1, … , 2ζmωm⌋. By the chosen scaling of the equations, the control variable ξ has the same dimension as the structural displacement x, and the gain factor β has the dimension of mass.

The stability of the velocity–velocity scheme follows directly from an extended energy balance relation, similar to the one used in Sim and Lee (1993). The gain factor matrix β consists of nonnegative diagonal elements, and thus the original control variables are conveniently replaced by a modified set of variables η = β1/2 ξ. When this substitution is used, and the control equation is pre-multiplied by β, the following block matrix format is obtained, (24)[MI][x··η··]+[D-(WΩcβ1/2)(WΩcβ1/2)TDc][x·η·] +[KΩc2][xη]=[f0] Stability follows from pre-multiplication of the dynamic equations by [x·T,η·T]. The equivalent energy is then defined via the first and the last matrix as (25)V=1/2x·TMx·+1/2η·Tη·+1/2xTKx+1/2ηTΩc2η while the time derivative of this function is given by the second matrix as (26)V·=-[x·TDx·+η·TDcη·]≤0 It is observed that the coupling terms appear as skew-symmetric contributions to the extended damping matrix, and thus do not enter directly into the energy balance relation.

sec.title: 4. Combined acceleration–position formats
sec.p: In the velocity-feedback format the actuator force is proportional to the derivative of the control variable ξ·, and the control variable is governed by a second-order differential equation with the structure velocity x· as input. The controlled structural response only depends on the product of these two factors via the frequency function (27)F(ω)G(ω)∝α(iω)(-iω)=αω2 Clearly, this product can be generated by a combination of position and acceleration feedback.

sec.title: 4.1. Simple acceleration–position format
sec.p: The simple acceleration–position feedback follows from the velocity feedback format by a simple variable transformation. There are two formats – one using the structure acceleration and the other using the structure displacement. The structure acceleration format is obtained by replacing ξ· with Ωcξ. Hereby the structure equation (22) takes the form (28)Mx··+Dx·+Kx=WΩc2βξ+f The corresponding control equation follows from differentiation of (23), whereby (29)ξ··+Dcξ·+Ωc2ξ=-WTx·· This set-up requires the acceleration of the structure and corresponds to the acceleration feedback format presented by Sim and Lee (1993) with a different, nonresonant, calibration procedure.

It may be convenient to use the alternative format combining structure displacement and controller acceleration feedback. In that case the velocity feedback formulation is modified by replacing Ωcξ with ξ· in (22) (30)Mx··+Dx·+Kx=Wβξ··+f In this case the control equation follows from (23) by integration as (31)ξ··+Dcξ·+Ωc2ξ=-Ωc2WTx In this form the feedback is in terms of structure displacement or deformation, typically available via strain–gauge measurement. This property was used by Kim et al. (2011b) under the name of ‘negative position feedback’.

These two combinations of acceleration and position are obtained directly from the velocity feedback format by a simple variable transformation, and thus the optimal parameters ωc and ζc are given by (18) and (20), respectively. The choice ωc = ωr was also made by Goh and Yan (1996) from observations of the root locus diagram, while the damping parameter ζc was selected to generate design at the bifurcation point. This is the design illustrated by the dashed curves in Figure 5. The stability analysis of the acceleration–position formats follows directly from that of the velocity format, demonstrating unconditional stability, irrespective of the details of the parameter calibration.

sec.title: 4.2. Extended acceleration–position feedback
sec.p: The velocity-feedback format, and thereby also the two simple acceleration–position formats given above, give optimal response characteristics for the structure velocity in the sense that the velocity amplification attains a near-level plateau around the resonance frequency. It may be desirable that this property applies to the structure displacement. This can be obtained by an extension of the acceleration–position format that introduces a phase-shift in the feedback. Here the extended format is developed in detail for the case combining structure acceleration with the extended form of the controller signal. This format has close similarity with the tuned mass absorber (Den Hartog, 1956, Krenk, 2005). The alternative format is briefly identified after this derivation.

The extended acceleration–position format follows from the simple format by including a phase-shift in the form of an equivalent damping term in the displacement variable. The effect of a general phase-shift has been investigated in Krenk and Høgsberg (2009), but the analogy with the tuned mass absorber suggests that a phase-shift prescribed directly in terms of the controller damping ratio ζc will lead to a plateau in the frequency response of the structure displacement, and therefore this magnitude of the phase-correction term is introduced directly in the present formulation. When this phase-shift is introduced into the control variable in the structure equation, the extended form of this equation is (32)x··+2ζrωrx·+ωr2x=α(ωc2ξ+2ζcωcξ·)+ωr2fkr The corresponding control equation is (33)ξ··+2ζcωcξ·+ωc2ξ=-x·· These equations correspond to those for the tuned mass absorber, when x is the structure displacement, ξ is the relative displacement of the tuned mass, and α is the ratio of the tuned mass to the structure mass.

Elimination of the control variable ξ between these equations gives the structure frequency response as (34)x=(ωc2-ω2+2iζcωcω)ωr2[ωr2-ω2+2iζrωrω)(ωc2-ω2+2iζcωcω)-αω2(ωc2+2iζcωcω]fkr It is observed that the extended format includes an extra cubic term in ω in the denominator. This term leads to modification of the expressions for the optimal value of the control parameters ωc and ζc.

sec.title: 4.3. Parameter calibration
sec.p: Calibration of optimal parameters for the tuned mass absorber have indicated that while the structural damping ζr complicates the analysis, the effect on the final control parameters is rather small. Therefore the calibration is based on the assumption ζr = 0, whereby the denominator of the frequency response takes the form (35)D2(ω)=ω4-[ωr2+(1+α)ωc2]ω2+ωr2ωc2 -2iζcωcω[(1+α)ω2-ωr2] The optimal controller parameters are determined by identification with the generic quartic equation (9) with equal modal damping.

The controller frequency is determined by expressing the characteristic reference frequency ω0 by the ratio of the coefficients to the linear and the cubic term, and also from the constant term. Elimination of ω02 between these equations gives (36)ωc=ωr1+α Thus, in the extended format the controller frequency ωc is smaller than the resonant frequency ωr of the uncontrolled structure. The same frequency tuning has been determined for the tuned mass absorber by a ‘fix point’ property of the displacement frequency response in Den Hartog (1956) and by a root locus analysis with equal modal damping in Krenk (2005). Thus, both these desirable properties are obtained by the extended format, when the phase delay in the force feedback in (32) is represented via ζc.

The controller damping ratio ζc is found by expressing the generic parameter χ from the coefficient of the quadratic term as well as from the coefficient of the cubic term. The result is identical to (19) for the velocity format. However, due to the difference in the optimal controller frequency, the optimal damping ratio ζc is different in the present case, where elimination of the parameter χ between the two equations determines the controller damping ratio as (37)ζc2=1/2α1+α This corresponds to the damping ratio obtained for the tuned mass absorber by a root locus analysis in Krenk (2005), wile the classic value determined from response curve characteristics is slightly lower with a coefficient of 3 8 (Den Hartog, 1956). In either case the modal damping ratio is approximately ζ≈1/2ζc. The full expression is given together with the results for all formats in Table 2.

The frequency response curves for the displacement and the velocity amplitude are shown in Figure 6. Like the frequency response curves of the velocity control format – and thereby simple acceleration–position control – the curves show a nearly level plateau around the resonance frequency. It is notable that by using the modified format the plateau of the displacement response becomes level, while the plateau of the velocity response increases with frequency as (ω/ω0). Figure 6.
Extended acceleration–position feedback: (a) displacement amplitude, (b) velocity amplitude, for α = 0.02, 0.04 and 0.08.

sec.title: 4.4. Multi-degrees-of-freedom implementation and stability
sec.p: When the control force expression in the structure equation (28) is extended by the time derivative term, the extended format takes the form (38)Mx··+Dx·+Kx=Wβ(Ωc2ξ+Dcξ·)+f where Dc is the diagonal damping matrix of the controllers. The corresponding control equation follows from differentiation of (23), whereby (39)ξ··+Dcξ·+Ωc2ξ=-WTx·· This format requires selected structure acceleration components.

Lyapunov stability is demonstrated by forming a positive definite energy functional V. Analogy with the tuned mass absorber would suggest that the control equation is multiplied by β, but maximum similarity with the other formats is attained here by introducing the modified control variable η = β1/2 ξ. The potential then takes the form (40)V=1/2x·TMx·+1/2(η·+β1/2WTx·)T(η·+β1/2WTx·) +1/2xTKx+1/2ηTΩc2η and the time derivative follows from the differential equations as (41)V·=-[x·TDx·+η·TDcη·]≤0 The energy function will always be nonincreasing, and for full structural damping it will be decreasing. Thus, the controlled system is unconditionally stable.

As in the case of the simple acceleration–position format, the role of the differential operators in the two coupling terms can be interchanged without affecting the response of the controlled system. In the present case the modification is obtained by replacing the control variable terms in the parenthesis of (38) by ξ·· whereby the structure equation takes the simple form (42)Mx··+Dx·+Kx=Wβξ··+f The corresponding control equation follows from application of the differential operator from the parenthesis in the structure equation (38) to the control equation (39), whereby (43)ξ··+Dcξ·+Ωc2ξ=-(Ωc2WTx+DcWTx·) The response and its stability properties are as in the original format (38)–(39), but the control equation now only requires the structural displacement and velocity, and not the acceleration.

sec.title: 5. Position feedback
sec.p: From an instrument point of view it is often advantageous to consider control formats based directly on position measurements by for instance strain gauges, piezoelectric patches or laser distance devices. In the case of position feedback the coupling terms do not contain time derivatives. Thus, the structural equation takes the form (44)x··+2ζrωrx·+ωr2x=αωr2ξ+ωr2fkr where the control variable ξ is conveniently scaled by ωr2. In the associated control equation the sensor input is the absolute or relative displacement x scaled by ωc2 (45)ξ··+2ζcωcξ·+ωc2ξ=ωc2x This feedback format is equivalent to the positive position feedback proposed by Fanson and Caughey (1990), and represents the governing equations for a piezoelectric shunt circuit with resistance and inductance placed in series, see Hagood and von Flotow (1991) and Caruso (2001). In the frequency domain the generalized displacement x is given by the frequency response relation (46)x=(ωc2-ω2+2iζcωcω)ωr2(ωr2-ω2+2iζrωrω)(ωc2-ω2+2iζcωcω)-αωr2ωc2fkr It is noted that the equations (44)–(45) produce a quasi-static feed-through signal that affects the apparent stiffness of the system. This effect is clearly illustrated by considering the zero frequency limit of the response relation (46), showing an amplification of (1 − α)−1 at ω = 0.

Various design procedures have been proposed for the pure position feedback control. In Friswell and Inman (1999) the system of equations are written in state-space form and the design is based on LQR (Linear–Quadratic–Regulator) optimal control, while the analytical approach in Hagood and von Flotow (1991) and Caruso (2001) relies on either maximum damping in the root locus analysis or minimization of the dynamic amplification of the structural response. Here, it is demonstrated that the simple equal modal damping format can also be applied to the case of position control, leading to balanced acceleration response. Furthermore, the simple position control format can be extended by a phase-shift, leading to balanced velocity response as described in Section 6.

sec.title: 5.1. Parameter calibration
sec.p: The calibration of the control parameters ωc and ζc is based on the denominator when ignoring the structural damping, i.e. ζr = 0, whereby (47)D3(ω)=ω4-[ωr2+ωc2]ω2+(1-α)ωr2ωc2 -2iζcωcω[ω2-ωr2] Also in this case the control parameters are determined by identification with the generic equal damping ratio quartic polynomial (9).

As before, the controller frequency is found by determination of the reference frequency ω0 from the ratio of the coefficients to the linear and the cubic term, and then from the constant term. Elimination of ω02 between these equations gives (48)ωc2=ωr21-α This corresponds to an increase of the controller frequency, determined by the quasi-static stiffness change imposed by the controller. The controller damping ratio ζc is found by expressing the generic parameter χ from the coefficient of the quadratic term as well as from the coefficient of the cubic term. When using the optimal frequency separation parameter λ=2/2 and the previously determined values ω02=ωr2=(1-α)ωc2, elimination of the parameter χ between these two equations determines the controller damping ratio as (49)ζc2=1/2α As for the previous format the resulting modal damping ratio is determined by ζ=etac, with the full expression given in Table 2.

The frequency response of the displacement and velocity amplitude for equal modal damping calibration of simple position control is shown in Figure 7. It is seen that the displacement control modifies the general features of the velocity control response by including an extra factor (ω0/ω) in the ‘plateau’ around resonance. Thus, for simple position control it is the acceleration response that obtains the feature of a level plateau, while the ‘plateau’ of the displacement response follows a (ω0/ω)2 dependence. This is likely to be undesirable, and as in the case of acceleration–position control this property can be improved by introducing a similarly modified format as discussed in Section 6. Figure 7.
Position feedback: (a) displacement amplitude and (b) velocity amplitude for α = 0.02, 0.04 and 0.08.

sec.title: 5.2. Multi-degrees-of-freedom implementation and stability
sec.p: The multi-degrees-of-freedom equation of motion corresponding to simple position feedback control can be formulated as (50)Mx··+Dx·+Kx=Wβξ+f while the control equation in this case is of the form (51)ξ··+Dcξ·+Ωc2ξ=Ωc2WTx By the chosen scaling of the equations the control variable ξ has the same dimension as the structural displacement x, and the gain factor β has the dimension of stiffness.

The stability condition follows from an extended energy balance relation – this time similar to the one used in Fanson and Caughey (1990). The original control variables are conveniently replaced by a modified set of variables η = β1/2 ξ. When this substitution is used and the control equation is pre-multiplied by β1/2Ωc-2 the following block matrix format is obtained, (52)[MΩc-2][x··η··]+[DΩc-1DcΩc-1][x·η·] +[K-(Wβ1/2)-(Wβ1/2)TI][xη]=[f0] This equation is an extended form of the standard second-order equation for structures. The damping matrix is positive definite if the original structure has positive definite damping, and otherwise positive semi-definite. In the present case the stability issue is associated with a reduction of the stiffness of the combined system represented by the off-diagonal blocks in the extended stiffness matrix.

The potential associated with the extended elastic energy, represented by the last matrix, can be expressed as (53)Ve=1/2[xT,ηT][K-(Wβ1/2)-(Wβ1/2)TI][xη] After rearrangement of the terms this potential takes the form (54)Ve=1/2xT(K-WβWT)x+1/2(η-β1/2WTx)T(η-β1/2WTx) The second term is a positive definite quadratic form. Thus, the combined system is stable, if the matrix of the first term is positive definite.

The requirement that the reduced stiffness in the first term of (54) is positive definite can be recast into flexibility format, whereby the dimension of the problem changes from the number of structural degrees of freedom n to the number of controllers m – typically a dramatic reduction. The result follows from the so-called Woodbury formula for the inverse of a matrix, see Householder (1975) or Golub and van Loan (1989). In the present notation, the Woodbury formula is (55)(K-WβWT)-1=K-1+K-1WHWTK-1 with the matrix H defined via its inverse as (56)H-1=β-1-WTK-1W It follows from this result that the reduced n × n stiffness matrix will be positive definite, if the m × m matrix H−1 is positive definite. The matrix H−1 is the difference between two positive definite matrices. If all the gain factors in the diagonal matrix β are sufficiently small, the matrix β−1 will dominate, thereby making H−1 positive definite. By increasing one or more of the gain factors sufficiently a limit will be reached, where H−1 becomes singular, and thus the inverse of the modified stiffness matrix (55) becomes unbounded. Thus, the condition that H−1 is positive definite is both necessary and sufficient for stability. In the case of a single controller the criterion becomes an explicit inequality in terms of the flexibility matrix K−1 as illustrated in the example.

sec.title: 6. Extended position feedback
sec.p: The simple position feedback format leads to frequency response curves with a marked slant of the plateau around resonance as shown in Figure 7. As in the case of the extended acceleration–position feedback this feature can be adjusted by adding a suitable time derivative term to either of the two coupling terms. When keeping the measured displacement x as input to the control equation, the additional term is included in the structure displacement equation, which then takes the form (57)x··+2ζrωrx·+ωr2x=α(ωc2ξ+2ζcωcξ·)+ωr2fkr where α is the nondimensional gain factor. The corresponding control equation is (58)ξ··+2ζcωcξ·+ωc2ξ=ωr2x Frequency factors have been introduced in all feedback terms to give x and ξ the same dimension. Elimination of the control variable ξ between the two equations gives the following frequency response expression (59)x=(ωc2-ω2+2iζcωcω)ωr2[ωr2-ω2+2iζrωrω)(ωc2-ω2+2iζcωcω)-αωr2(ωc2+2iζcωcω]fkr A similar frequency response would be obtained, if the time derivative were included in the right-hand side of the control equation (58) instead of the right-hand side of the structure equation (57). While the simple position feedback format treated in Section 5 corresponds to a series RL circuit, the extended position format represents a parallel RL circuit, see Caruso (2001).

sec.title: 6.1. Parameter calibration
sec.p: As in the previous cases, the calibration of the control parameters ωc and ζc is based on the denominator when ignoring the structural damping, i.e. ζr = 0, whereby (60)D4(ω)=ω4-[ωr2+ωc2]ω2+(1-α)ωr2ωc2 -2iζcωcω[ω2-(1-α)ωr2] The reference frequency ω0 is determined from the ratio of the coefficients to the linear and the cubic term, and elimination of ω02 between these relations then gives the controller frequency as (61)ωc2=(1-α)ωr2 In contrast to the simple position format the controller frequency decreases with increasing gain α in the extended position control format. Similarly, the generic parameter χ is expressed from the coefficient of the quadratic term as well as from the coefficient of the cubic term. Elimination of χ between these relations then gives the controller damping ratio as (62)ζc2=1/2α1-α In this case the resulting modal damping ratio is ζ≈1/2ζc.

The frequency response amplitude of displacement and velocity for the equal modal damping design of the extended position control format is shown in Figure 8. The figure confirms the conjecture that the modified format exhibits a ‘plateau’ around resonance with an extra frequency factor (ω/ω0). Thus, the modified position control format leads to a level plateau for the velocity response, and reduces the frequency dependence of the displacement ‘plateau’ from (ω0/ω)2 to (ω0/ω). Figure 8.
Extended position feedback: (a) displacement amplitude, (b) velocity amplitude, for α = 0.02, 0.04 and 0.08.

sec.title: 6.2. Multi-degrees-of-freedom implementation and stability
sec.p: For the extended position control of multi-degrees-of-freedom systems the equation of motion is conveniently written in the form (63)Mx··+Dx·+Kx=Wβ(Ωc2ξ+Dcξ·)+f The control equation of the extended position format is of the form (64)ξ··+Dcξ·+Ωc2ξ=Ωc2WTx It is noted that in this format the gain factor elements in β have the dimension mass in order to obtain a direct formulation of the extra time derivative term.

Stability is investigated by reformulating the equations to a form that closely resembles that of the acceleration–position format. This is attained by introducing a new variable η, defined by the relation (65)Ωc2(η+WTx)=Ωc2ξ+Dcξ· Elimination of the original control variable from the structure equation (63) gives (66)Mx··+Dx·+[K-W(ΩcβΩc)WT]x=W(ΩcβΩc)η+f. When the differential operator [Ωc2+Dc(∂/∂t)] is applied to the control equation (64), combination of the terms gives the following equation (67)η··+Dcη·+Ωc2η=-Ωc2WTx·· The two equations (66) and (67) of the extended position format correspond to the equations (28) and (29) for the first acceleration–position format, when it is observed that the stiffness in the current format is reduced by a contribution proportional to the gain matrix β. Thus, the present control format is stable, if the reduced stiffness matrix is positive definite. By an argument using the Woodbury formula for the inverse already used in (55) and (56) for the direct position control format this corresponds to the matrix (68)H-1=[ΩcβΩc]-1-WTK-1W being positive definite. It is seen that this result corresponds precisely to the stability limit in the form (56) for the position format, when it is observed that the present format is normalized to use a gain factor with dimension mass, while the position format was normalized with gain factors of dimension stiffness.

sec.title: 7. Performance on flexible structure
sec.p: The numerical example in this section illustrates the performance of the various control formats when applied to a single resonant controller acting on a flexible structure. For a single collocated sensor–actuator pair the frequency domain representation of the equations of motion is (69)(-ω2M+iωD+K)x=wfc+f where the scalar control force is represented in terms of the frequency transfer function F(ω) as (70)fc=βF(ω)ξ and the corresponding resonant control equation is (71)(-ω2+2iζcωcω+ωc2)ξ=G(ω)wTx In the above expressions β is the scalar gain parameter, while F(ω) and G(ω) are frequency-dependent functions, representing the specific selected control format. For a single controller system the connectivity array reduces to a column vector w.

sec.title: 7.1. Modal equations and control formats
sec.p:
The calibration of the various resonant control formats is based on the free vibration characteristics of the structure. The controller is targeted at mode r with mode shape vector ur, here normalized to unit modal mass urTMur=1. If the controller is placed at a point, where the local controller force produces significant excitation of other nonresonant modes, it is desirable to include a correction for this effect in the calibration in the form of an added ‘background flexibility’, see Preumont (2002) and Krenk and Høgsberg (2009). An important aspect of this technique is that it modifies the calibration, while the implementation is otherwise unaffected. Examples of the application of this technique for the extended acceleration–position format to multiple modes of wind turbine blades and three-bladed rotors have been given in Svendsen et al. (2011) and Krenk et al. (2012), respectively. These techniques can also be used on the other resonant control formats, but this aspect will not be dealt with here. The calibration is therefore based on a single-mode representation of the response, given as (72)x=urxr where xr is the modal coordinate. Substitution of (72) into both (69) and (71), followed by pre-multiplication of (69) with urT, gives the scalar structural equation (73)(-ω2+2iζrωrω+ωr2)xr=νrβF(ω)ξ and the control equation (74)(-ω2+2iζcωcω+ωc2)ξ=νrG(ω)xr The parameter νr = wT ur represents the modal amplitude of the structure at the sensor–actuator location. Because ur is normalized to unit modal mass the parameter 1/ν12 represents the effective mass observed by the controller. The structural damping is assumed orthogonal with modal damping ratio ζr. The characteristics of the individual resonant control formats considered in the previous sections are represented by the factor νr2βF(ω)G(ω). Note, that the modal representation introduces a scaling by νr2. For all the formats this factor can be absorbed directly into the control gain, whereby (75)α=νr2β The expressions for the remaining frequency transfer functions G(ω) and F(ω) are summarized in Table 1, where it should be noted that the velocity–velocity format in Section 3 is represented by the acceleration feedback format given in (28) and (29), and in Sim and Lee (1993). In the case of a single controller the limit of stability for the position feedback formats in (56) and (68) can be written explicitly as (76)αstab=νr2βstab=(νrωr)2(wTK-1w)-1 The factor (νr/ωr)2 represents the modal flexibility at the control location. In the present example the targeted mode is the first vibration mode of the structure, i.e. r = 1.

In all the resonant control formats considered here the control parameters consist of a reference frequency ω0 at which the amplification typically takes a simple form, the resonance frequency of the controller ωc, the bandwidth parameter taking the form of a damping ratio of the controller ζc, and a relation between the controller parameter ζc and the resulting modal damping ratio ζ. The expressions for these parameters in terms of the gain parameter α based on an idealized two-degrees-of-freedom structure without structural damping are summarized in Table 2. For most realistic design situations these formulae can be linearized in α.

sec.title: 7.2. Structural beam model
sec.p:
Figure 9 shows a single collocated sensor–actuator pair acting on a simply supported Bernoulli–Euler beam of length ℓ, with constant bending stiffness EI and constant mass ρA per unit length. The beam is discretized by identical finite elements of length ℓe with transverse displacement wj and cross sectional rotation θj as the degrees of freedom of node j. In the present case the beam is divided into 10 elements, whereby ℓe = ℓ/10, leading to 11 nodes and 22 structural degrees of freedom. Figure 9.
(a) Simply supported beam with collocated sensor–actuator pair. (b) Beam element with transverse displacement and rotation as degrees of freedom.

The undamped natural frequencies of the first three vibration modes of the numerical beam model are ωrρAℓ4π4EI=1.0000, 4.0004, 9.0048 for r=1,2,3 Thus, the present discretization recovers the natural frequencies of the first three modes of the corresponding continuous beam with an error of less than 0.1%. Numerical errors associated with the finite element model are therefore negligible in the following examples.

Two sensor–actuator locations are considered: a/ℓ = 0.5 and 0.2, corresponding to nodes 6 and 3 of the beam model, respectively. The control acts on the absolute transverse displacement and the connectivity vector can therefore be written as (77)w=[0…0,1,0…0]T where the single unit value is located either at degree of freedom 11 or 5. For these two control locations 1/(ν12ρAℓ)=0.50 and 1.45, respectively, which shows that the effective mass observed by the controller increases as the sensor–actuator pair moves away from the center of the beam.

sec.title: 7.3. Root locus analysis
sec.p: Initially the performance of the various resonant control formats is demonstrated by a root locus analysis, where the trajectories of the complex valued natural frequencies ω are plotted in the complex plane for increasing gain α. For the two control locations a/ℓ = 0.5 and 0.2 the expression (76) gives the corresponding position format stability limits αstab = 0.98 and 0.83. In the following analysis the interval of the gain is 0 ≤ α ≤ 0.2 < αstab, i.e. well within the stability limit of position control. The complex valued natural frequencies are determined as the Eigenvalues of the system of equations (69,71) with β given in (75) and G(ω) and F(ω) defined in Table 1.

Figures 10–13 show the root locus diagram for the four resonant control formats: acceleration feedback, extended acceleration feedback, position feedback and extended position feedback. In Figure 10 the top row represents the control location a/ℓ = 0.5, while the bottom row represents a/ℓ = 0.2. The relation between the results for the two controller locations is similar for the other cases, and therefore the second row has been omitted in Figures 11–13. In the figures on the left-hand side, the solid curves represent the trajectories in the complex plane of the two natural frequencies associated with the present calibration of resonant control of the first mode. These curves are comparable to those in Figure 3(b) for the idealized system. The asterisks represent the natural frequencies at gain values α = 0.02, 0.04 and 0.08, respectively. The dotted curves represent the semi-circular path of Figure 3(a) for χ = 0.02, 0.04 and 0.08. The curves are only plotted up to the bifurcation point ωb, represented by square markers in the figures. The circles represent the desired roots at ± 45° corresponding to λ=2/2. At zero gain the natural frequencies recover the undamped natural frequency ω1. For α > 0 the trajectories of simple acceleration and position feedback in Figures 10 and 12 follow the desired 45°-paths with good agreement, while the trajectories of the extended formats in Figures 11 and 13 branch slightly off towards the imaginary axis. The present calibration method with separated frequencies is compared to the calibration at the bifurcation point ωb, as proposed in Goh and Yan (1996) for acceleration feedback and in Caruso (2001) for the displacement feedback formats. Bifurcation point calibration is a special case of equal modal damping and therefore results in the same value of the controller frequency ωc as the present method, given in Table 2. The expression for ζc in the bifurcation point calibration is obtained from the present values by multiplication with 2. The dashed curves in Figures 10–13 represent the root locus corresponding to bifurcation point calibration, and the crosses indicate the roots at α = 0.02, 0.04 and 0.08. It is seen that the flexibility of the structure leads to some deviation from the ideal double root property used in the design and furthermore a distinct difference between the damping ratio of the two modes occur for the controller location a/ℓ = 0.2. Figure 10.
Acceleration feedback: Root locus diagram (a) and (c) and modal damping ratios (b) and (d) for a/ℓ = 0.5 (a) and (b) and 0.2 (c) and (d).
Figure 11.
Extended acceleration feedback: Root locus diagram (a) and modal damping ratios (b) for a/ℓ = 0.5.
Figure 12.
Position feedback: Root locus diagram (a) and modal damping ratios (b) for a/ℓ = 0.5.
Figure 13.

The plots on the right-hand side in Figures 10–13 show the modal damping ratio of the first mode, determined as ζ = Im[ω]/|ω|. The solid curves represent the present calibration procedure with separated resonance frequencies, while the dashed curves represent the results from bifurcation point calibration. For the present calibration method it is seen that the equal modal damping property is virtually exact for a/ℓ = 0.5, while for a/ℓ = 0.2 small discrepancies occur. Furthermore, it is seen that α = 0.08 produces modal damping ratios ζ ∼ 0.1, which is more than sufficient for most problems in structural dynamics. Note, that although the root loci of the two extended formats in Figures 11 and 13 deviate from the idealized 45°-curves, the equal modal damping property is maintained. Thus, for the calibration procedure with separated frequencies the ideal properties of the simplified two-degrees-of-freedom model used in the parameter calibration are well conserved also when applied to a flexible structure. In contrast, the bifurcation calibration procedure appears to be less robust when applied to flexible structures and more sensitive to placement of the sensor–actuator pair, with loss of the equal modal damping property for a/ℓ = 0.2 as shown in Figure 10(d). This is in accordance with the common observation, e.g. from stability analysis of structures, that bifurcation points may be quite sensitive to parameter variations.

sec.title: 7.4. Frequency response analysis
sec.p: The frequency response characteristics of the beam are illustrated by introducing a time harmonic load with angular frequency ω and constant spatial distribution with intensity p, (78)f(x,t)=peiωt The amplitude of the equivalent load vector is constructed as (79)f=[,-mn,fn,0,fn,0,…,fn,0,fn,0,n,mn]T where fn = pℓe is the equivalent nodal force and mn=pℓe2/12 is the equivalent moment acting locally at the supports. The frequency response amplitude is then obtained by combining (69)–(71) into (80)x=(-ω2M+iωD+K-βF(ω)G(ω)ωc2-ω2+2iζcωcωwwT)-1f while the amplitude of the control force is subsequently determined as (81)fc=βF(ω)G(ω)wc2-ω2+2iζcωcωwTx In the frequency response analysis structural damping is included via the Rayleigh-type damping matrix D=ζminωminM+ζminωminK with minimum damping ratio ζmin = 0.005 occurring at the frequency ωmin = ω1.

Figures 14–17 show the frequency response amplitudes for the four resonant control formats: acceleration feedback, extended acceleration feedback, position feedback and extended position feedback. As for the root locus analysis the top and bottom rows in Figure 14 represent a/ℓ = 0.5 and 0.2, respectively. The figures on the left-hand side show the dynamic amplification of the transverse displacement at the center of the beam, i.e. the ratio of the dynamic displacement amplitude xdyn to the corresponding static deflection xstat without influence of the control. The solid curves represent the response amplitude from the present calibration method, while the dashed curves represent the bifurcation calibration. Each figure contains curves for α = 0.02, 0.04 and 0.08. The figures on the right-hand side present the frequency amplitude of the corresponding control force fc, normalized by the equivalent load f1 = 2pℓ/π for the first sinusoidal vibration form. Figure 14.
Acceleration feedback: Displacement amplitude (a) and (c) and control force amplitude (b) and (d) for a/ℓ = 0.5 (a) and (b) and 0.2 (c) and (d).
Figure 17.
Extended position feedback: Displacement amplitude (a) and control force amplitude (b) for a/ℓ = 0.5.

The dynamic amplification is reduced for increasing gain α. Good agreement is observed between the frequency response curves for the beam in Figures 14–17 and the corresponding frequency curves in Figures 4–8 for the idealized system. For instance, the response curves of the extended formats in Figures 15 and 17 are more flat around resonance than the pure feedback formats in Figures 14 and 16, respectively. In fact, the response curves of the extended acceleration feedback in Figure 15 are near optimal with respect to displacements, while the extended position feedback in Figure 17 is optimal with respect to velocity, leading to slightly inclined displacement frequency curves. It is notable that in the case of position–position control the extended format requires a larger control force than the basic format. In contrast, the magnitude of the control force in the two acceleration–position formats are quite similar. Figure 15.
Extended acceleration feedback: Displacement amplitude (a) and control force amplitude (b) for a/ℓ = 0.5.
Figure 16.
Position feedback: Displacement amplitude (a) and control force amplitude (b) for a/ℓ = 0.5.

The reduction in the response amplitude is directly associated with the damping introduced by the control, and for all formats the curves correspond to α≈2ζc2≈8ζ2, where ζ is the desired damping introduced by the resonant vibration control. As indicated in Section 7.5 structural damping and damping from resonant vibration control are practically additive. When reducing the observability/contrallability by decreasing a/ℓ the control force fc is increased correspondingly. In the case of the acceleration feedback formats in Figures 14 and 15 the control force curves are practically flat around resonance, and it has been demonstrated that the extended acceleration format leads to a force maximum at ω0 that is independent of the gain parameter α, Krenk (2005). However, the bandwidth of the control force increases with α. For the position feedback formats in Figures 16–17 the curves of the control force are inclined slightly, whereby the maximum control force increases with α. It is clearly seen from the response curves that the bifurcation point calibration (dashed curves) results in an undesirable peak in the dynamic amplification at resonance. This means that although the bifurcation point calibration leads to maximum modal damping in a root locus analysis, the associated proximity of the two roots introduces constructive interference and thereby additional amplification in the response analysis. Thus, the present calibration procedure constitutes a reasonable compromise between large and equal modal damping, and effective response reduction at limited control effort.

sec.title: 7.5. Controller design procedure
sec.p: A simple design procedure for the control parameters can be developed based on the effective damping ratio of the controlled system. As illustrated in the examples actual design will typically involve a gain parameter α < 0.1, and the gain parameter will then be given in terms of the controller damping ratio via (82)ζc2≈1/2α where the equality is exact for the simple formats. The controller damping ζc is obtained from its contribution ζ to the modal damping ratio (83)ζ≈1/2ζc The numerical results from structures including structural damping demonstrate that the effective modal damping ratio ζeff of the two controlled modes is well represented by simply adding the corresponding structural damping ratio, whereby (84)ζeff=ζr+1/2ζc This definition of an effective damping ratio represents the dynamic amplification of the controlled system at the reference frequency ω0 via the approximate, but quite accurate, relation (85)xdynxsat≈12ζeff This formula gives the combined response of the two closely spaced controlled modes in the classic format for single-mode response with orthogonal damping.

The validity of the design formulae is illustrated in Table 3 for the present beam example using the four control formats and the two positions of the controller. The structural damping of the resonant mode is taken as the rather large value ζr = 0.05 in order to illustrate the robustness of the superposition formula (84) for ζeff. To facilitate comparison between the various cases, the table includes entries for the three gain parameter values α = 0.02, 0.04, 0.08. The controller damping ratio ζc then follows from (82). These values are used in the numerical model to calculate the dynamic amplification at the center of the beam at the frequency ω = ω0. The calculated dynamic amplification is then compared with the corresponding amplification calculated from the explicit formula (85) in terms of the effective damping ratio ζeff given by (84). The results in the table indicate a very high degree of accuracy of the explicit formulae (82)–(85) for predicting the dynamic amplification when using equal modal damping design with any of the control formats – with the possible exception of the simple displacement format which has a slightly larger error. Thus, the damping-based design procedure constitutes a uniform method for resonant controller calibration. Table 3.

sec.title: 8. Conclusions
sec.p: The properties of resonant control have been studied and a simple design principle is developed for a family of resonant controllers using a collocated sensor–actuator pair with acceleration, velocity or position feedback. The design principle is of the pole-placement type. The poles are determined by two properties: (a) equal damping ratio of the two modes generated by the interaction of the structure and the resonant controller, and (b) optimal separation of the frequencies of these two modes to avoid constructive interference. While the first property has been used in separate designs for several of the special cases, the second property replaces the often used design at the bifurcation point of the root locus diagram. The separation of the modal frequencies typically leads to a reduction by 2 in the amplification factor at resonance relative to the bifurcation point design. Furthermore, the essential equal modal damping property of the present design procedure appears to be quite robust, also when applied to control of flexible structures. The family of resonant control formats include the basic forms of velocity–velocity, position–acceleration and position–position control, and also an extended form of the basic formats that leads to a more level plateau of the frequency response curve. The simple design principles lead to compact explicit formulae for the controller parameters in terms of controller frequency and controller damping ratio. Furthermore as a consequence of the design principles the damping ratio of each of the generated resonant modes has a damping ratio that is half of the controller damping ratio. This relation enables an explicit design procedure starting from the desired damping ratio of the involved modes.
